review.title: Temporal anomaly detection: calibrating the surprise
review.abstract: We propose a hybrid approach to temporal anomaly detection in user-database access data -- or more generally, any kind of subject-object co-occurrence data. Our methodology allows identifying anomalies based on a single stationary model, instead of requiring a full temporal one, which would be prohibitive in our setting. We learn our low-rank stationary model from the high-dimensional training data, and then fit a regression model for predicting the expected likelihood score of normal access patterns in the future. The disparity between the predicted and the observed likelihood scores is used to assess the "surprise". This approach enables calibration of the anomaly score so that time-varying normal behavior patterns are not considered anomalous. We provide a detailed description of the algorithm, including a convergence analysis, and report encouraging empirical results. One of the datasets we tested is new for the public domain. It consists of two months' worth of database access records from a live system. This dataset will be made publicly available, and is provided in the supplementary material.

metadata.title: Temporal anomaly detection: calibrating the surprise

sections.heading: 2 Related Work
sections.text: Intrusion detection methods can be roughly grouped into two main categories: rules-based and learning-based methods [Santos et al., 2014]. This paper deals with the latter, within a timeframe. Temporal analysis [Lee et al., 2000] models the timing and frequency of user access to the database. Approaches based on dependencies and relationship analysis look for systematic redundancy in the event column protocol [Chung et al., 1999, Kamra et al., 2008]. Sequence alignment methods methods [Srivastava et al., 2006] look for frequent sequences of events, then monitor system behavior by checking for repetition of these sequences. Some methods collect different statistical information about user access to the database and use it to model normal behavior [Spalka and Lehnhardt, 2005, Mathew et al., 2010, Lee et al.] rely solely on data that is detectable during a 2002-Sali application.

sections.heading: 3 Our approach
sections.text: To detect anomalous access patterns, we start by defining a probable model for normal access patterns. Our approach is based on learning a basic set of parameters based on different user intervals, and modelling the deviation of the temporal model from the stationary level. We assume that the data is provided as a sequence of consecutive time intervals in which for each time interval a different number of objects is available in which the number of access intervals is different. The aim of the algorithms is to provide an application-specific parameter.The aim of the algorithms is an anomalous score for each new access to Bt (i, j) = I [User i).The object j] is an application-specific parameter.The aim of the algorithms is an anomalous score for each new access model observed after the general distribution phase.

sections.heading: 4 The Algorithm
sections.text: We describe the two phases of the algorithm: the training phase and the anomaly detection phase. In the training phase, the algorithm has access to a training set S = (B1,.., BT), where Bt is exclusively binary access matrices of consecutive time intervals. However, the algorithm splits the training set into two parts, S1 = (B1,.., BT1), S2 = (BT1 + 1,., BT). S1 is used to find an estimate for the probable stationary model π, as described in Section 4.1. S2 is used to adjust the log probability regressor w. The full training phase is provided in Section 4.2.In the anomaly detection phase, an access matrix is provided as input for each time interval, and the algorithm gives an anomaly.

sections.heading: 4.3 Unseen objects: cold start
sections.text: In the above algorithm description, we avoid the problem of users or objects that are observed for the first time only after the first phase of training, i.e. after the first phase of training. Such new elements could be observed for the first time during the regression phase or later during the deployment phase, since anomalous results are calculated. In the context of collaborative filtering, this problem is commonly known as the cold start problem. [Su and Khoshgoftaar, 2009] In our setting, the challenge is to assign the probability values to the matrices Bt, which include new rows or columns that do not appear in the systems. [Previous solutions to the cold start problem in the context of collaborative filtering have suggested finding an existing user whose access pattern is most similar to that of the new user, and assigning the new user the same prediction as the existing user or a weighted score of the most similar users. [Shardanand Maes, 1995, Our set-up is not specific, as we try to predict something else).

sections.heading: 5 Experiments
sections.text: We tested our algorithms on several datasets. The first dataset is TDA, described in Section 1, and provided in the supplementary matrix. TDA represents the ability of users to access a database that is evaluated over a two-month period. The other two datasets are the Movie Rating Datasets from NetFlix, 2009, Bennett et al., 2007) and MovieLens, 2016). The rating timestamps were used to generate the aggregated time intervals. Here, the objects are movies, and an access occurs when a user reviews a movie. None of the available datasets contained known anomalous accessibility. [2002] analyzed SQL patterns in such an application. These approaches are inapplicable to our setting, since they rely on sequential data, while we have only aggregated data from each time interval. The problem of change-point detection, while not strictly a subset of anomaly or intrusion detection, is of some relevance to the temporal setting [Takeuchi and Yamanishi, 2006, Tartakovsky et al., 2006, Höhle, 2010, Khaleghi and Ryabko, 2012, 2014]. A natural approach is to model the temporal process via a Markov or Hidden Markov Model, as was done in Görnitz et al. [2015]. These approaches, however, cannot be feasibly applied to our setting, because of the high dimensionality of the aggregated access matrices.

The problem of change-point detection, while not strictly a subset of anomaly or intrusion detection, is of some relevance to the temporal setting [Takeuchi and Yamanishi, 2006, Tartakovsky et al., 2006, Höhle, 2010, Khaleghi and Ryabko, 2012, 2014]. A natural approach is to model the temporal process via a Markov or Hidden Markov Model, as was done in Görnitz et al. [2015]. These approaches, however, cannot be feasibly applied to our setting, because of the high dimensionality of the aggregated access matrices. Additionally, our data is aggregated over time intervals rather than being sequential, which precludes a clean application of Markovian techniques. Lakhina et al. [2005] employ a low rank concatenation of entropy matrices for every feature at different intervals, achieved by PCA.

A standard approach for finding a low-rank estimate [Fazel, 2002] is to minimize the mean-squared error of the matrix difference, and regularize using the trace norm, which is a convex relaxation of the low-rank constraint:
Our probabilistic model, and our low-rank assumption on π̄, are similar to those studied in Davenport et al. [2014], Hsieh et al.

Our probabilistic model, and our low-rank assumption on π̄, are similar to those studied in Davenport et al. [2014], Hsieh et al. [2015]. However, in these works it is assumed that only one access matrix drawn from π̄ is available, while we have several matrices available at training time.

Existing generalization bounds [Davenport et al., 2014, Shamir and Shalev-Shwartz, 2014, Hsieh et al., 2015] give guarantees for the mean-squared-loss of the solution to the optimization problem in Eq. (3), for the case where B is a single matrix drawn according to π̄. Our approach to finding the low-rank structure is similar to the above, however instead of considering a single binary matrix B, we use the average matrix B̄ = 1 T1 ∑T1 t=1Bt. In Appendix A in the supplementary we prove a generalization bound for F (B̄, λ), which converges to the true low-rank model as T1 increases. An efficient solution to the unconstrained version of Eq. metadata.abstractText: We propose a hybrid approach to temporal anomaly detection in user-database access data — or more generally, any kind of subject-object co-occurrence data. Our methodology allows identifying anomalies based on a single stationary model, instead of requiring a full temporal one, which would be prohibitive in our setting. We learn our low-rank stationary model from the high-dimensional training data, and then fit a regression model for predicting the expected likelihood score of normal access patterns in the future. The disparity between the predicted and the observed likelihood scores is used to assess the “surprise”. This approach enables calibration of the anomaly score so that time-varying normal behavior patterns are not considered anomalous. We provide a detailed description of the algorithm, including a convergence analysis, and report encouraging empirical results. One of the datasets we tested is new for the public domain. It consists of two months’ worth of database access records from a live system. This dataset will be made publicly available, and is provided in the supplementary material.
